answers.text: set forth the process for Puerto Rico to be admitted as a state of the Union

qas.question: What did Senator Heinrich's bill require?

answers.text: a binding referendum to be held in Puerto Rico asking whether the territory wants to be admitted as a state.

qas.question: What would happen in the event of a yes vote in this referendum?

answers.text: the president would be asked to submit legislation to Congress to admit Puerto Rico as a state

plausible_answers.text: set forth the process for Puerto Rico to be admitted as a state of the Union
a binding referendum to be held in Puerto Rico asking whether the territory wants to be admitted as a state

qas.question: What did Senator H.R. Heinrich's bill require?

plausible_answers.text: the president would be asked to submit legislation to Congress to admit Puerto Rico as a state

qas.question: What would happen in the event of a no vote in this referendum?
Who was asked to ratify the Puerto Rico Senate?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>On May 15, 2013<b4_0/><a0_0/>, Resident Commissioner Pierluisi introduced H.R. 2000 to Congress to "<a1_0><b5_0>set forth the process for Puerto Rico to be admitted as a state of the Union<b5_0/><a1_0/>," asking for <b8_0>Congress<b8_0/> to vote on ratifying Puerto Rico as the 51st state. On February 12, 2014, Senator Martin Heinrich introduced a bill in the US Senate. The bill would require <a2_0><b6_0>a binding referendum to be held in Puerto Rico asking whether the territory wants to be admitted as a state<b6_0/>.<a2_0/> In the event of a yes vote, <a3_0><b7_0>the president would be asked to submit legislation to Congress to admit Puerto Rico as a state<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
